item.source: How to get JS to do stuff in order

item.title: How to get JS to do stuff in order
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Koolvin, post:6, topic:336415”]OOPS! Thank you! Haha, my bad.

Edit: Is that function truly needed? I don’t think it is.

Edit 2:

[quote author=la­wl link=topic=432785.msg3176995#msg3176995 date=1270948036]

This is the support given?

.slideUp( [ duration ], [ callback ] )
duration: A string or number determining how long the animation will run.
callback: A function to call once the animation is complete.
^^ straight from jquery docs.
Example:

function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); })); } Callbacks basically tell jQuery (in this case) what to do after the operation given has completed.

thats slightly incorrect,

function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", function() { $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); }})); } [/quote]
That is incorrect =p function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", function() { $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); } );}); } With your method, you misaligned the labyrinth of )}'s. Also, that function is unneeded.

[hr]Edit 3:
To OP:$('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); becomes$('form#edit').html(data).slideDown("medium");[/quote]
its not necessary, but to make it a callback it is. if you remove the function(){ it would just be executed instantly, instead of being called as a callback

i wasn’t about to fuck around with formatting in a browser textarea, but zerofreeze has it just about right…

Read full topic
item.source: How to get JS to do stuff in order

item.title: How to get JS to do stuff in order
item.dc:creator: @Zero_Freeze ZeroFreeze
item.description:
@Zero_Freeze wrote:

^ pretty sure that’s wrong

this should be right:

function edit(objId) {
	$('form#edit').slideUp("medium", function() {
		$.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) {
			$('form#edit').html(data);
                        $('form#edit').slideDown("medium");
		});
	});
}

Read full topic

This is the support given?

.slideUp( [ duration ], [ callback ] )
duration: A string or number determining how long the animation will run.
callback: A function to call once the animation is complete.
^^ straight from jquery docs.
Example:

function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); })); } Callbacks basically tell jQuery (in this case) what to do after the operation given has completed.
[/quote]
thats slightly incorrect,

That is incorrect =p function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", function() { $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); } );}); } With your method, you misaligned the labyrinth of )}'s. Also, that function is unneeded.

[hr]Edit 3:
To OP:$('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); becomes$('form#edit').html(data).slideDown("medium");

item.title: How to get JS to do stuff in order
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Koolvin, post:4, topic:336415”]This is the support given?

.slideUp( [ duration ], [ callback ] )
duration: A string or number determining how long the animation will run.
callback: A function to call once the animation is complete.
^^ straight from jquery docs.
Example:

function edit(objId) { $('form#edit').slideUp("medium", $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId }, function(data) { $('form#edit').html(data); $('form#edit').slideDown("medium"); })); } Callbacks basically tell jQuery (in this case) what to do after the operation given has completed.[/quote]
thats slightly incorrect,

function edit(objId) {
	$('form#edit').slideUp("medium",
	function() {
	$.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId },
	function(data) {
		$('form#edit').html(data);
		$('form#edit').slideDown("medium");
	}}));
}

item.title: How to get JS to do stuff in order
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.source: How to get JS to do stuff in order

item.title: How to get JS to do stuff in order
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

i’ve always had trouble getting javascript to run code in the exact order it’s written in. for example:

      function edit(objId) {
        $('form#edit').slideUp("medium");
        $.get("/edit.ajax.form.php", { id: objId },
          function(data) {
            $('form#edit').html(data);
            $('form#edit').slideDown("medium");
          });
      }

that’s supposed to slide the form out of view (slideUp), then send the ajax request, read the response, put the response in the form, then slide the form back into view (slideDown).

it doesn’t do this tho - first it sends the ajax request, reads the response, puts the response in the form, slides the form up, then slides the form down. as you can imagine this looks pretty retarded to a user.

Read full topic
item.source: How to get JS to do stuff in order
